hero.title: The Eucharist
hero.quote: I am the living bread that came down from heaven
hero.subtitle: Central sacrament of the Catholic faith

definition.title: Definition
definition.subtitle: The Eucharist is the sacrament instituted by Jesus Christ at the Last Supper

cards.title: Central Sacrament
cards.description: Source and summit of all Christian life, where Christ becomes present under the species of bread and wine.

cards.title: Real Presence
cards.description: Christ is truly present under the appearances of bread and wine. It is not just a symbol.

cards.title: Communion
cards.description: It unites us in communion with Christ and among ourselves as members of the Body of Christ.

history.title: History
history.subtitle: From the Last Supper to our days

timeline.title: The Last Supper
timeline.description: Jesus instituted the Eucharist during the Last Supper with his apostles, taking bread and wine and saying: "This is my body... This is my blood". He commanded them to do this in memory of him.
timeline.quote: Do this in remembrance of me

timeline.title: The Early Church
timeline.description: The first Christians celebrated the "breaking of bread" following Jesus' command. Saint Paul describes this practice in his letters.
timeline.quote: For I received from the Lord what I also passed on to you

timeline.title: Liturgical Development
timeline.description: Throughout the centuries, the Eucharistic celebration developed in different liturgical traditions, always maintaining the essential elements established by Christ.

theology.title: Theological Meaning
theology.subtitle: The profound mystery of the Eucharist in the Catholic faith

aspects.title: Sacrifice
aspects.description: The Eucharist actualizes in an unbloody manner the sacrifice of Christ on the cross. It is the same sacrifice, not a repetition.

aspects.title: Communion
aspects.description: It is the sacred banquet where we receive Christ as spiritual food, uniting us intimately with Him.

aspects.title: Presence
aspects.description: Christ is truly, really and substantially present under the Eucharistic species.

items.title: Sanctifying Grace
items.description: Increases divine life in the soul

symbols.title: Eucharistic Symbols
symbols.subtitle: The sacred signs that help us understand the mystery

items.title: Bread
items.description: Symbol of basic food, represents Christ as the bread of life that sustains our spiritual existence.

items.title: Wine
items.description: Represents the blood of Christ shed for us. It is a symbol of joy and the new covenant.

items.title: Cross
items.description: The central symbol of Christianity, present in every Eucharist as a reminder of the redemptive sacrifice.

items.title: Assembly
items.description: The gathered community represents the Body of Christ, united in the celebration of the Eucharistic mystery.

items.title: Light
items.description: Candles represent Christ as the light of the world, who illuminates the darkness of sin.

items.title: Heart
items.description: Symbol of Christ's infinite love, who gives himself completely in every Eucharist.

prayers.title: Eucharistic Prayers
prayers.subtitle: Traditional prayers for before and after communion

prayers.title: Prayer of Preparation
prayers.text: Lord, I am not worthy that you should enter under my roof, but only say the word and my soul shall be healed. Prepare my heart to receive you with faith, hope and charity.

prayers.title: Act of Faith
prayers.text: My Lord Jesus Christ, I firmly believe that you are present in this Sacrament, true God and true man.

prayers.title: Thanksgiving
prayers.text: I thank you, Lord Jesus Christ, for having nourished me with your Body and Blood. May this communion be for me a source of eternal life.

prayers.title: Personal Offering
prayers.text: Soul of Christ, sanctify me. Body of Christ, save me. Blood of Christ, inebriate me. Within your wounds, hide me.

universal.title: Universal Prayer
universal.text: O God, who in this wonderful Sacrament left us a memorial of your Passion, grant us, we beseech you, so to venerate the sacred mysteries of your Body and Blood that we may always experience within ourselves the fruit of your redemption.
universal.author: Prayer of Saint Thomas Aquinas

deepening.description: The Eucharist is an inexhaustible mystery. We invite you to continue your spiritual and theological formation on this central sacrament of our faith.
